data.title: C syntax highlighter underscore problem in markdown files
data.body:
In a markdown file, when I'm using C or C++ syntax highlight, names **starting with a single
 underscore** will break the syntax highlighter for the remaining part of the whole markdown file.

This happens with names in special contexts. For example this block will break highlighting:

```
~~~C
f(_);
~~~
```

But not these one:

```
~~~C
struct _;
~~~
```

**Atom version:** 1.3.3

**OS and version:** Windows 7 SP1

**Installed packages:** this is a fresh installation with all the standard packages

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1475458/12294557/bac52fb8-b9fb-11e5-92c5-ed78f20cba6f.png)

data.title: Atom crashes on startup, reinstalling and deleting user data doesn't help
data.body:
I am trying to use Atom 1.3.3 on Windows 10 Pro 64-bit. Previous versions of Atom worked until around version 1.3.2 when it started crashing.

I tried deleting all the user data I could find. I deleted these folders specifically: [user]\AppData\Local\atom, [user]\AppData\Roaming\Atom, and [user] \ .atom. (If there are any others, please let me know!)

I uninstall, delete all data, and reinstall the latest version. When I start Atom for the first time, it shows a window with three tabs: "untitled", "Welcome" and "Welcome Guide". The Welcome Guide is open and shows normal contents. Immediately, a crash dialog appears saying "The editor has crashed, Please report..." and no further details.

I have three options. "Close Window" quits. "Reload" makes Atom crash again. "Keep It Open" makes the window blank.

When the window is blank, most options are unresponsive. Trying to "Open in Dev Mode" makes Atom crash in the same way.

The Bug Reporting Guide says to attach a crash report with a stack trace, but I cannot for the life of me find it on my system. If Atom makes a crash report, where does it go? This is especially strange because atom/CONTRIBUTING gives instructions for Mac but no other platforms.

Opening in safe mode doesn't help.
Adding a firewall exception doesn't help.
Rebooting doesn't help. (issue #9985)
No blob-store folder is ever created. (issue #10015)

Atom is completely unusable.

data.title: Scrollbar not deactivated after dismissing right-click context menu
data.body:
The scrollbar is not deactivated after dismissing the right-click context menu if you accidentally right-click while scrolling with the left mouse button.

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Click and hold the left mouse button while over a scrollbar. The scrollbar appears wider, as expected.
2. While holding the left mouse button, click the right mouse button.
3. Let go of the left mouse button
4. At this point the context menu will be displayed. Move the mouse pointer off of the scrollbar and click somewhere else to dismiss the menu. The mouse pointer must be off of the scrollbar to reproduce this.
5. After clicking, the context menu disappears. The scrollbar remains in its widened state. Clicking and typing within the pane work as normal.
6. Move the mouse pointer back over any part of the scrollbar. The file is scrolled to the position where the mouse pointer enters the scrollbar.
7. Left-click on the scrollbar to deactivate it, causing it to appear narrow again. At this point, the scrollbar will now behave as normal.

**Expected behavior:**

This happens for both horizontal and vertical scrollbars. Expected behavior is that after dismissing the context menu, the scrollbar is deactivated.

**Observed behavior:**

See steps 5 and 6 above.

**Screenshots and GIFs**

![anim](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12118969/12285223/6b3c20d8-b97d-11e5-8017-adda90bd35f2.gif)

**Atom version:** 1.3.3
**OS and version:** Linux Mint 17.2 64-bit

**Installed packages:**

asciidoc-preview@0.6.0
hard-wrap@1.0.1
language-asciidoc@0.12.0
language-rust@0.4.5
vim-mode@0.64.0

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Unsure. Haven't tried.
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: No
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes

data.title: Stop babel from logging to stderr during compilation
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10056
Refs https://github.com/atom-minimap/minimap/issues/426

This stops babel from logging to stderr in the case where the user has the `DEBUG` environment variable set to `*` or `babel`. Babel doesn't have an API (except for the env var) for disabling this logging, so I've monkey-patched its `Logger` class, and created a feature request for adding a programmatic API: https://phabricator.babeljs.io/T6955.

data.title: Sudden onset of poor performance: profiler shows time spent in channel.onread
data.body:
I've been using Atom for a while now and generally haven't had any problems. But today it just became unusable. I don't have any explanation for why it became unusable today, since I haven't upgraded anything.

Any keypress can freeze the editor for several seconds, though sometimes it's possible to get off a volley of code before it stops working again. But essentially it's impossible to use.

It pegs the CPU at 100%. As an aside, the internet performance has been bad today in general (high ping and dropped packets), but I don't have any evidence or reason to believe this is related.

Conditions reproduced in:
- Editing Go code, dockerfiles and plain text files
- The general editor with no files open (browsing the settings and the Ctrl-P menu)
- 1.1.0, Linux amd64 Ubuntu 15.10, Intel graphics.
- 1.3.3, same.
- 1.3.3 Safe mode, same.

A profile shows all of the time being spent in channel.onread (I couldn't find any reference to this in the issue tracker)

![screenshot from 2016-01-12 16-01-48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/438648/12268723/d96d4470-b945-11e5-9a45-389f74d06dac.png)

data.title: core:select-down can skip lines
data.body:
Atom 1.3.2 on OS X 10.10.5.

This behavior is asymmetric with core:select-up.

Repro:
1.  Enter text such as the following.  The numbers and pipes shouldn't be typed and simply indicate the line number and the edge of the editor.  Lines 1 and 4 are empty.
   
   ```
   1|
   2|;; The optional step argument determines how far `partition` moves down the ...
   3|;; next chunk.  If not specified, `step` defaults to `size`.
   4|
   5|(partition 2 1 [1 2 3 4 5])
   ```
2.  Position the cursor on line 2 somewhere to the right of the first column, say - between the "e" and "n" of "argument".
3.  Press Up Arrow.
4.  Press Shift + Down Arrow.  Text through "argum" in line 2 is selected.
5.  Press Shift + Down Arrow.  Text through "not spec" in line 3 is selected.
6.  Press Shift + Down Arrow.
7.  Press Shift + Down Arrow.

Expected:

Step 6 selects text "through line 4", meaning that it selects from where the cursor was on step 2, through all of the contents of line 3, and including the newline at the end of line 3.

Step 7 selects text through the end of line 5.

Actual:

Step 6 selects through the end of line 3.  The difference from "Expected" is that the newline at the end of line 3 isn't selected.

Step 7 completely skips like 4 and selects through the end of line 5.

This animated GIF shows the above repro steps and the result:

![2016-01-11-atom-shift-down-can-skip-lines](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/380880/12256636/9c2b1322-b8b3-11e5-880c-41b2bfb63e23.gif)

data.title: Fixed the indentation logic (updated)
data.body:
Previously the logic lacked handling of multiple matches of the
increase/decrease regexs, so things like the following javascript
would not be handled correctly (the last line would be indented).

``` js
if (test) {
  foo({a:1
  })};
var t = "this should be at indentation 0";
```

Fixed that.

Also revisited the logic regarding decreaseIndent and
decreaseNextIndent. It did not seem very logical that decreaseIndent
did _not_ correspond to increaseIndent: decreaseIndent regarded the
current line whereas increaseIndent regarded the next line (just like
decreaseNextIndent). For that reason I renamed decreaseIndent to
decreaseThisIndent and decreaseNextIndent to decreaseIndent. This way
we also avoid a whole lot of issues related to the concept of
decreaseNextIndent, because most of the language packages I looked at
have not yet adopted it but the semantics of decreaseIndent had
changed. So now the semantics of decreaseIndent is back to what it was
and decreaseThisIndent is the new concept.

Also now using the tokenized line to determine whether a in-/decrease
pattern appears within a quoted string (and ignoring it in that case),
rather than requiring regexes for checking whether or not the
occurrence is within a quoted string or not -- the examples I saw for
that were wrong, too (e.g., things like `/} [^"] /` are non-sense,
because things like `} var x = "hey"` are perfectly fine). One really
needs to reason about balanced quotation to get it right, and the
tokenizer already does that for us, so let's use it rather than
reinventing the wheel. The decrease/increase regexes can now be much
simpler in the language packages.

In this version we use decreaseIndentPattern as the default value for decreaseThisIndentPattern, which is OK, because that pattern is never applied (matched) more than once, which was the previous behavior.

data.title: Theme not changing
data.body:
OS: Manjaro Linux
Atom version:1.3.3

I use the  Source code (tar.gz) to install. In Atom Setting can't change ui theme and syntax theme. The default theme is one dark.if I change the ui theme or syntax theme,the theme will become atom-dark theme. At the moment, I cannot choose other theme.

data.title: Sometimes when starting ATOM, cpu usage spikes, clicking on the status icon (octocat spinner) shows its processing 2000+ editText requests
data.body: Eventually if I let it sit, it will successfully process all 6000+ requests. But this takes several minutes.If I  exit atom before it finishes I see two node processes still running, both taking 100% cpu.

data.title: Blurry Font and Ripple Effect Menu Bar!
data.body:
This same thing happens on Atom, Visual Studio and Light Table, Brackets its fine.

Text is very distorted and blurry and it gets better if I hover with a mouse over part of a text (only that part gets better) if I don't move the mouse that area gets bad again, also the menu bar gets something like Ripple effect or like a page is opening and its moving, could someone explain why this happens?!

OS: Windows 10 Pro 1151

![screenshot 32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9529847/12248643/1299d6a4-b8bb-11e5-8ecd-45ec7793f5fc.png)
![screenshot 20](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9529847/12248644/12afc068-b8bb-11e5-8194-28d69ca0eb29.png)

data.title: Explicitly guard against decorating destroyed markers
data.body:
Fixes #10014

/cc @steelbrain - It looks like the linter is passing markers that have been destroyed to `TextEditor::decorateMarker`. We had a hard time reproducing it, so I can't give you precise steps. It seems to happen when editing after closing split panes. When I reproduced it, I was undoing and redoing repeatedly, but I'm not sure if that's related.

data.title: Atom constantly freezes
data.body: I am using Atom for the first time.  It constantly freezes, so I have to restart Atom all the time.  I have added several plugins to Atom, including Emmet (which I customized to work with tab), atom-beautify, etc.  I don't know if they cause Atom to freeze.  However, the menu bar is functioning; I just can't type text or enter the cursor.  The side bar also has been frozen.

data.title: Remove release-notes
data.body:
Since it’s been reporting the wrong release notes, it’s doing more harm than good :disappointed: 

We’ll link to the release notes from About now.

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13760/12246027/07da1fee-b87a-11e5-9843-b87dbbf3c975.jpg)

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: How to run a shell command in atom without a package
data.body:
Hi,
I love atom and I use the package 'Script' to run my code normally, but I am currently writing a feature for a package and I need to run a shell command and I am not sure how to do this in atom without the 'Script' package.  Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks :smiling_imp:
